message_1: A beverage company claims that the average volume of their soft drink cans is 355 milliliters with a standard deviation of 5 milliliters. A sample of 50 cans was taken from a production line and their average volume was found to be 352 milliliters. Calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true average volume of the cans.
message_2:
To calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true average volume of the cans, we will use the following formula:

Confidence Interval = x̄ ± (Z * (σ / √n))

where:
x̄ = sample mean (352 milliliters)
Z = Z-score for a 95% confidence interval (1.96)
σ = population standard deviation (5 milliliters)
n = sample size (50 cans)

First, we need to calculate the standard error (σ / √n):

Standard Error = 5 / √50 ≈ 0.7071

Next, we will calculate the margin of error (Z * Standard Error):

Margin of Error = 1.96 * 0.7071 ≈ 1.3859

Now, we can calculate the confidence interval:

Confidence Interval = 352 ± 1.3859

Lower Limit = 352 - 1.3859 ≈ 350.6141 milliliters
Upper Limit = 352 + 1.3859 ≈ 353.3859 milliliters

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true average volume of the cans is approximately (350.6141, 353.3859) milliliters.
